imperatives

in today's lesson we will take a look at
imperatives in English imperative

statements are used to give an order
command instruction warning and to make

a request the imperative is one of the
three moods of the English verb the

other two being indicative and
subjunctive

a basic example of an imperative is give
me that coat please to make an

imperative it is necessary to use the
infinitive of the verb without using to

for example sit down
come here stand there to make a negative

imperative put do not or don't before
the verb for example don't go

do not walk on the grass don't talk if
you are including yourself in the

imperative you can use let's to show
that this is the case for example let's

stop now let's have some lunch let's
walk the negative of let's is let's not

let's not tell her about it let's not
fight let's not go there

when it comes to giving orders it is
unusual for adults to tell each other

what to do unless one is in a position
of authority orders are often given to

children and to animals teachers often
give both instructions and orders so it

would be fair to say that imperatives
are used a lot by teachers and those

with some form of authority
another type of imperative is the

warning to stress the importance of
something when expressing danger is a

warning you warn a person of danger the
intonation of a warning is always

stressed with the last word of the
sentence often being higher in tone than

the others for example watch out look
out

don't cross sit down now you will notice
in the last example that the tone at the

end of the sentence drops this helps to
enforce the warning so is to make the
sentence seem less like a request

another type of imperative is advice you
offer your thought or comment on

something as a way of offering help
advice is normally stressed so as to get

the helpful message across don't quit
your job yet wait until your thoughts

are a bit clearer don't eat too much
don't go now wait for a while finally we

have the request to request is to ask
someone to do something in a polite way

a request is not a warning examples of
requests include please take a seat

please wait here please don't smoke here
it is worth remembering that an

imperative sentence does not require a
subject as the pronoun U is implied so

to recap an imperative can be an order a
warning a piece of advice or a request
